column1: The Bonding Curve
A unique bonding curve market is associated with each Original NFT
column2: which governs all Print Tokens related to that Original NFT. The bonding curve market aggregates funds from sales of the relevant Print Tokens
column3: allowing holders of a Print Token to  “burn” their Print Token in exchange for a portion of the funds held in the bonding curve pool applicable to that Print Token (the “Burn Reserve”).

column1: Bonding curves are nascent markets and technology
column2: and EulerBeats makes no guarantee that any user will be able to use the bonding curve market to burn their asset at all – much less at any particular price. The “burn” price may be lower than the purchase price for the particular Print Token
column3: depending on the specific bonding curve at the time the Print Token is “burned”. You acknowledge and accept the risk that there may be vulnerabilities and a risk of loss of funds.

column1: Print Token Transaction Proceeds
When you create and purchase a Print Token
column2: the proceeds of that transaction are allocated as follows:

column1: EulerBeats Genesis Release
Burn Reserve : 90%
Original NFT Holder : 8%
EulerBeats :  2%
EulerBeats Enigma Release
Burn Reserve : 84%
Original NFT Holder : 8%
EulerBeats :  8%
Gas Fees

Ethereum requires a transaction fee (a “Gas Fee”) to be paid for every transaction that occurs on the Ethereum network. This includes all transactions of Original NFTs and Print Tokens.  Gas Fees are consumed by the blockchain platform in processing your transaction and are not refundable.  You can read more about Gas Fees here.
Third-Party Platform Fees
The purchase and sale of Original NFTs or Print Tokens on third-party marketplaces or platforms like OpenSea are subject to the terms and conditions of those marketplaces

column1: Arbitration Rules

The arbitration will be administered by the American Arbitration Association (“AAA”) in accordance with the Commercial Arbitration Rules and the Supplementary Procedures for Consumer Related Disputes (the “AAA Rules”) then in effect
column2: except as modified by this Dispute Resolution Section. (The AAA Rules are available at https://www.adr.org/mediation or by calling the AAA at 1–800–778–7879.) The Federal Arbitration Act will govern the interpretation and enforcement of this Dispute Resolution Section.

column1: Arbitration Process

A party who desires to initiate arbitration must provide the other party with a written Demand for Arbitration as specified in the AAA Rules (The AAA provides a form Demand for Arbitration). The arbitrator will be either a retired judge or an attorney licensed to practice law and will be selected by the parties from the AAA’s roster of arbitrators. If the parties are unable to agree upon an arbitrator within seven (7) days of delivery of the Demand for Arbitration
column2: then the AAA will appoint the arbitrator in accordance with the AAA Rules.

column1: Arbitration Location and Procedure
Unless you and EulerBeats otherwise agree
column2: the arbitration will be conducted in the state where you reside
column3: with the option for you to participate telephonically to the extent the AAA Rules allow. If your claim does not exceed $10
column5: then the arbitration will be conducted solely on the basis of the documents that you and EulerBeats submit to the arbitrator
column6: unless you request a hearing or the arbitrator determines that a hearing is necessary. If your claim exceeds $10
column8: your right to a hearing will be determined by the AAA Rules. Subject to the AAA Rules
column9: the arbitrator will have the discretion to direct a reasonable exchange of information by the parties
column10: consistent with the expedited nature of the arbitration.

column1: Arbitrator’s Decision

The arbitrator will render an award within the time frame specified in the AAA Rules. The arbitrator’s decision will include the essential findings and conclusions which the arbitrator based its award on. Judgment on the arbitration award may be entered in any court having jurisdiction over the arbitration award. The arbitrator’s award of damages must be consistent with the terms of the “Limitation of Liability” subsection of these Terms as to the types and amounts of damages for which a party may be held liable. The arbitrator may award declaratory or injunctive relief only in favor of the claimant and only to the extent necessary to provide relief warranted by the claimant’s individual claim. If you prevail in arbitration you will be entitled to an award of attorneys’ fees and expenses
column2: to the extent provided under applicable law. EulerBeats will not seek
column3: and hereby waives all rights it may have under applicable law to recover
column4: attorneys’ fees and expenses if it prevails in arbitration
column5: unless such arbitration is found by the arbitrator to be frivolous under the standards of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 11(b) and in that case EulerBeats shall be entitled to recover attorneys’ fees in addition to any damages awarded to it.
